Alright, so there was this French guy named Peter the Great. Well, "the Great" wasn't his last name, we'll get to that. He was a well known pirate at this point, but not a fabled leader yet.
So Peter had a crew of 29 men on a large canoe-like boat. Like me after this game, they had suffered failure after failure. They were on their last rope.
Starving, exasperated, and exhausted, Peter's crew hunted for a Spanish merchant vessel not far from the island of Hispaniola. Their provisions were giving out.
Peter's men were on the brink of despair, when they sighted a large ship in the distant waters. They pooled the last of their strength together and paddled their giant canoe to the ship.
To the dismay of the pirates, the ship they found was a war vessel of the Spanish fleet. It was as if a lion sensed a big ol' fat deer, but instead pounced on an colossal elephant.
To Peter, their only option was clear. They could either ambush and capture the warship, or die alone in the ocean with empty bellies.
The Spanish captain paid little attention to Peter and his seemingly insignificant canoe as they approached. He decided to haul them on deck and question them if they came closer, but nothing more.
Peter waited until nightfall to approach the ship undetected. He sawed a hole into the canoe so it would sink as they boarded. The pirates would have no escape, except by death.
The pirates climbed the ship like cats, and pounced on the unsuspecting Spaniards. They were stupefied. It appeared these men were demons who had dropped from the sky!
The Spaniards who fought were quickly cut down by desperate, starving pirates. The rest surrendered without a fight. The ship was theirs!
Peter the Great had earned his title. He later sailed back to France and retired a gentleman of wealth and leisure.
